image.altText: Gallagher speaks on the senate floor.

items.synopsis: Senator Gallagher fiercely denies she misled parliament over statements she made in relation to Brittany Higgins, telling the Senate that recent events have harmed progress in making parliament safer.

image.altText: a young brunette woman smiling into the camera

items.synopsis: Twenty-four-year-old Julia-Mary Lane, who is known as JM, has been living in Canada since early January and is heading into her third night in the wilderness of British Columbia.

title.children: Family fears for Australian woman missing after going hiking in Canadian bear country

image.altText: One hand on a laptop's trackpad while another hand holds a credit card

items.synopsis: Fraudulent sites are mimicking real brands, going as far as stealing logos and brand design. Melinda did the checks but they weren't enough — so here are the signs to look out for.

title.children: Instead of $200 boots, Melinda was sent $2 sunnies. Then came the emails

items.synopsis: Young people are increasingly concerned about the future of the planet and want to have a say, according to organisers of the Make It 16 campaign.

image.altText: Black a frame with sign saying fever clinic and a yellow arrow, sitting in front of a red wall with 'emergency' written on it

items.synopsis: Each Omicron wave has had distinguishing features and Australia's fifth wave has grown so slowly many may not have realised it had begun. So why has this most recent wave been so drawn out, and what has its impact been on our health and health systems?

title.children: Australia is in another COVID wave, but it's not like the others

image.altText: Two police officers in uniform stand and look at the bottom of an overturned bus

items.synopsis: Police allege the driver "lost control" of a wedding bus as it entered a roundabout before crashing in NSW's Hunter Valley on Sunday night, killing 10 people.

title.children: Driver going 'too quick' before fatal bus crash in NSW's Hunter Valley, police allege

image.altText: Fiona Mardling smiling in a portrait, wearing a blue clinic uniform and a stethscope around her neck.

items.synopsis: Nurses outside of hospitals say they are not being used to their full capacity, with one group blaming Medicare rules for holding them back.

title.children: Fiona has three decades of experience as a nurse but Medicare says her time is worth $12.70

image.altText: A close up shot of a man wearing glasses and a baseball cap

items.synopsis: The 23-year-old man accused of running down Perth police officer Anthony Woods faces court as the charge against him is upgraded to murder.

title.children: Man who allegedly mowed down police officer faces murder charge in Perth court

image.altText: A Shinkansen bullet train on a track in a city.

items.synopsis: Some 34 countries have high-speed rail or are about to get it. But in the decades since it was first proposed for Australia, no local plan for high-speed rail has got further than the drawing board, writes Philip Laird.

title.children: Four decades and millions spent on studies: Why Australia is still waiting for high-speed trains

image.altText: People stand over a map of the world.

items.synopsis: With only 24 hours in a day, researchers have crunched the numbers and worked out what the average global human day looks like.

title.children: This is what the average human day looks like. How do Australians compare?

image.altText: A composite image including the Karen's Diner sign and a notice on the door showing a termination of the lease.

items.synopsis: Viral social media restaurants Karen's Diner close, leaving former workers alleging sexual and physical harassment claims in doubt.

title.children: Karen's Diner employees' concerns remain unresolved as liquidators appointed to multiple restaurants

image.altText: A young man smiles at the camera

items.synopsis: Tributes are pouring in for a Tasmanian man in his 20s who was killed in the tragic Hunter Valley crash on Sunday night, as the driver of the bus is released on bail.

title.children: Outpouring of grief for Tasmanian killed in Hunter Valley bus crash

image.altText: A man smiling standing in front of a cool room fridge of lamb

items.synopsis: Farmer Colin Harper was fed up with being a price taker — and not a price maker — when it came to selling his lambs. To solve the problem, the Riverina farmer decided to step away from the saleyards.

title.children: Sick of having lamb prices dictated to him by supermarkets, this farmer went direct to the customer

image.altText: Ukrainian service members of the 55th Separate Artillery Brigade fire a Caesar self-propelled howitzer towards Russian troops.

items.synopsis: Ukraine says troops recaptured seven villages from Russian forces in the south-east, as France promises more military aid to Kyiv to help with its counteroffensive.

title.children: 'The enemy's losses are exactly what we need': Zelenskyy claims counteroffensive making progress

image.altText: Three flight attendants — a man in a dark suit, and two women wearing red and black dresses — stand in a plane smiling.

items.synopsis: The airline is scrapping its gender-based uniform guidelines — and it's not the first, with many airlines having updated their rules to allow staff to show their authentic selves.

title.children: Qantas to allow flat shoes, make-up and long hair on crew of any gender — but what does this mean for inclusivity?

image.altText: a woman wearing glasses talking into microphones at a press conference

items.synopsis: Kate Jenkins, who led the inquiry into the culture of parliament, says the workplace has improved — but warns of the potential damage being done to victims of sexual assault by recent reporting.

title.children: 'It has changed': Kate Jenkins says parliament culture is getting better

image.altText: Queensland budget winners and losers 2021 illustration

items.synopsis: Powered by a windfall of coal and oil royalties, the Queensland budget for 2023/24 has seen cash splashed across a number of areas.

title.children: Who are the winners and losers in this year's Queensland budget?

image.altText: A drone shot of rows of houses in Shell Cove, Wollongong's south.

items.synopsis: The value of Australian homes rebounds to $9.9 trillion, but higher interest rates means consumers are more wary of getting into the property market. And the ASX turns higher after US stocks reach a 13-month high.

title.children: Home prices rise but consumers think it's a bad time to buy a house, ASX reverses course

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market reversed early losses to end higher as investors hope the US central bank will keep interest rates on hold at its meeting this week. The ASX 200 index put on 0.2 per cent to 7,139 with technology stocks driving the gains after a 13-month high on Wall Street. But energy firms and miners limited the rise, after oil and iron ore prices slumped overnight. The latest US inflation figures are out tonight and investors are hoping that consumer prices eased back in May. The CME Fed Watch Tool has a 81.5% chance that the Federal Reserve will keep rates on hold at 5 per cent to 5.25 per cent. Meanwhile, China's central bank cut a short-term lending rate for the first time in 10 months to boost its slowing economy. That also helped the Australian share market recover lost ground. And Japan's Nikkei 225 was bolstered by technology firms to a new 30 year high.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX rises ahead of US inflation data and Fed decision

children.content: The Australian share market reversed early losses to end higher as investors hope the US central bank will keep interest rates on hold at its meeting this week.
The ASX 200 index put on 0.2 per cent to 7,139 with technology stocks driving the gains after a 13-month high on Wall Street.
But energy firms and miners limited the rise, after oil and iron ore prices slumped overnight.
The latest US inflation figures are out tonight and investors are hoping that consumer prices eased back in May.
The CME Fed Watch Tool has a 81.5% chance that the Federal Reserve will keep rates on hold at 5 per cent to 5.25 per cent.
Meanwhile, China's central bank cut a short-term lending rate for the first time in 10 months to boost its slowing economy.
That also helped the Australian share market recover lost ground.
And Japan's Nikkei 225 was bolstered by technology firms to a new 30 year high.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: More on today's market update from Domino's Pizza. The pizza chain plans to close down its stores in Denmark and close up to 70 under performing corporate owned stores. That's about 2 per cent of its 3,827 stores globally. It will partner with experienced franchisees to run up to 75 corporate owned stories that have improved their performance, and reduce the number of new stores that it opens. Domino's will also bring pizza dough making in-house at its stores in south east Asia, and close its Brisbane based construction and supply services subsidiary. It estimates the moves will save it $53 million to $59 million annually. "Wherever there is the potential for reducing duplication, or achieving increased efficiencies, we will pursue these with continuous focus on delivering for our franchise network," said Domino's boss Don Meij. "Making the decision to close any store is a difficult one, but for these stores it is the right one.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Domino's cuts fat

children.content: More on today's market update from Domino's Pizza.
The pizza chain plans to close down its stores in Denmark and close up to 70 under performing corporate owned stores.
That's about 2 per cent of its 3,827 stores globally.
It will partner with experienced franchisees to run up to 75 corporate owned stories that have improved their performance, and reduce the number of new stores that it opens.
Domino's will also bring pizza dough making in-house at its stores in south east Asia, and close its Brisbane based construction and supply services subsidiary.
It estimates the moves will save it $53 million to $59 million annually.

"Wherever there is the potential for reducing duplication, or achieving increased efficiencies, we will pursue these with continuous focus on delivering for our franchise network," said Domino's boss Don Meij.
"Making the decision to close any store is a difficult one, but for these stores it is the right one.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Queensland has unveiled a record $12.3 billion budget surplus thanks to a rise in coal royalties which generated more than $15 billion in revenue. The money will fund cost of living relief, including a $550 electricity rebate for households, and 15 hours a week of free kindergarten for all four year olds from next year. Queensland treasurer Cameron Dick said the record surplus would be used to pay down debt. "This is the largest budget surplus ever recorded by any state or territory," he said. "Our budget surplus is larger than all but four surpluses delivered by the government of the Commonwealth of Australia, all more than 15 years ago. More from Queensland political reporter Rachel Riga.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Queensland's record budget surplus

featuredLink.title: Power bill rebates and free kindy: $1.6b in new cost-of-living relief announced for Queenslanders

children.content: Queensland has unveiled a record $12.3 billion budget surplus thanks to a rise in coal royalties which generated more than $15 billion in revenue.
The money will fund cost of living relief, including a $550 electricity rebate for households, and 15 hours a week of free kindergarten for all four year olds from next year.
Queensland treasurer Cameron Dick said the record surplus would be used to pay down debt.
"This is the largest budget surplus ever recorded by any state or territory," he said.
"Our budget surplus is larger than all but four surpluses delivered by the government of the Commonwealth of Australia, all more than 15
years ago.
More from Queensland political reporter Rachel Riga.

image.altText: A Denver NBA player smiles and puts his hands on his head in celebration after his team wins a title.

image.altText: Smoke is rising from a building that has been heavily damaged by a missile strike.

items.synopsis: Russia launched a "massive missile" attack overnight on the central Ukrainian city of Kryvyi Rih, killing at least three people and wounding 25 and damaging civilian infrastructure, Ukrainian officials said early on Tuesday.

title.children: At least three dead, scores wounded after 'massive missile' attack by Russia on civilian buildings in Kryvyi Rih, in central Ukraine

image.altText: A man with greying hair and a blonde woman pose for a photo at the Hollywood Walk of Fame.

image.altText: Two men crouched over a coffin with a woman wrapped in a sheet inside.

image.altText: More revelations in the Jeffrey Epstein investigation

items.synopsis: JPMorgan Chase has agreed to pay about $430 million to settle a lawsuit by Jeffrey Epstein's victims who had accused the bank of being the financial conduit that allowed him to continue operating a sex trafficking operation.

title.children: Jeffrey Epstein victims reach $430 million settlement with JPMorgan Chase bank

image.altText: Half the image is underwater showing fish and mangrove roots, the top half is the mangrove canopy and sun peeking through.

items.synopsis: K + S Salt Australia has released environmental studies which it believes show it should be able to develop a major project within a nationally significant wetland.

title.children: World's largest salt company defends project as opponents say saltworks will 'kill' fragile ecosystem

image.altText: A composite image of three people on stage wearing long gowns

items.synopsis: This year's Tony Awards were almost cancelled because of the Writers Guild of America strike blazing through Hollywood. But the show must go on — and so it did.

title.children: No scripts and a win for inclusivity — Tony Awards make history amidst Hollywood's writer's strike
